BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 17, 1922

SENIOR -PROM TO BE BRILLIANT AFFAIR
LAST SOCIAL FUNCTION OF CLASS TO BE HELD NEXT TUESDAY
Final preparations have been made for the Senior Prom which is to be held next Tuesday, February 21. This event, the crowning glory of the fourth year man's college life, will
last from 9:30 P. M. until 1 A. M. The quality of the affair has been foreshadowed from
the masterful futuristic advance notices from the brush of Badillo to the attractive souvenirs
obtained by the Prom Committee.
Seidemann's Orchestra has been obtained to supply the music and from all indications
the C. E. Hall will be the scene of "joy uncon fined."

FORD SEDAN TO AID IN PSYCHOLOGICAL TESTS

The Psychology Department
has recently been enabled to enter on a new field of research as
the result of a fund which has
been raised outside of the University. Members of the department have for some time been desirous of studying and testing the
vestibular function; but-in order
to conduct this work, subjects had
to be brought from some distance.
In order to facilitate the work, a
man interested in the project, believing that the investigating will
have far-reaching and beneficial
results, has put up sufficient
Money to provide for the transportation of patients to be used in the
test. A Ford Sedan has been
bought and every other means will
be used to administer the fund
economically and to make it go as
far as possible. Members of the
department will assume the responsibility of caring for and running the machine.

ARRANGEMENTS COMPLETED FOR
JUNIOR PROM

"MAKE FOR A PATHLESS CAMPUS"

Anybody who has visited
Swarthmore College must have
been impressed with the beautiful
smooth campus, unspoiled by the
beaten paths of thoughtless students. Placed at various prominent points on the campus are
neat little reminding signs bearing the unoffensive admonition,
"Make for a Pathless Campus."
These signs have done a great
deal toward making the Swarthmore campus what it is today—
one of the most beautiful college
settings in the United States. '
It is with sorrow and shame
that we observe "cow paths" daily
increasing in prominence at several conspicuous points on the
Hopkins campus. We know that
it is awfully easy to take short
cuts between the buildings, but
why not take thirty seconds longer and use the walks that are provided. One very easily gets in the
habit of making certain short cuts
all the time. This is all right when
one is in a hurry to get to class.
but it is pure laziness when there
is plenty of time. When we consider' how much a pathless campus aids the appearance of the
University, and how little trouble
it is to get out of the short cut
habit, it should not be hard to enlist the hearty co-operation of the
entire student body in aiding to
preserve the beauty of our grassy
lawns.
As the habitual offenders might
find it rather hard at first to break
themselves of their lazy habits,
we would suggest that the Student Council erect notices similar
to those at Swarthmore and then
make it a matter of pride to prevent the formation of any more
ugly short cuts. These notices
would not be offensive or abrupt,
but would simply be a gentle reminder given in the spirit of cooperation and good fellowship.

UALITY HOP

FORD SEDAN TO AID IN PSYCHOLOGICAL TESTS

The Psychology Department
has recently been enabled to enter on a new field of research as
the result of a fund which has
been raised outside of the University. Members of the department have for some time been desirous of studying and testing the
vestibular function; but-in order
to conduct this work, subjects had
to be brought from some distance.
In order to facilitate the work, a
man interested in the project, believing that the investigating will
have far-reaching and beneficial
results, has put up sufficient
Money to provide for the transportation of patients to be used in the
test. A Ford Sedan has been
bought and every other means will
be used to administer the fund
economically and to make it go as
far as possible. Members of the
department will assume the responsibility of caring for and running the machine.

ARRANGEMENTS COMPLETED FOR
JUNIOR PROM

"MAKE FOR A PATHLESS CAMPUS"

Anybody who has visited
Swarthmore College must have
been impressed with the beautiful
smooth campus, unspoiled by the
beaten paths of thoughtless students. Placed at various prominent points on the campus are
neat little reminding signs bearing the unoffensive admonition,
"Make for a Pathless Campus."
These signs have done a great
deal toward making the Swarthmore campus what it is today—
one of the most beautiful college
settings in the United States. '
It is with sorrow and shame
that we observe "cow paths" daily
increasing in prominence at several conspicuous points on the
Hopkins campus. We know that
it is awfully easy to take short
cuts between the buildings, but
why not take thirty seconds longer and use the walks that are provided. One very easily gets in the
habit of making certain short cuts
all the time. This is all right when
one is in a hurry to get to class.
but it is pure laziness when there
is plenty of time. When we consider' how much a pathless campus aids the appearance of the
University, and how little trouble
it is to get out of the short cut
habit, it should not be hard to enlist the hearty co-operation of the
entire student body in aiding to
preserve the beauty of our grassy
lawns.
As the habitual offenders might
find it rather hard at first to break
themselves of their lazy habits,
we would suggest that the Student Council erect notices similar
to those at Swarthmore and then
make it a matter of pride to prevent the formation of any more
ugly short cuts. These notices
would not be offensive or abrupt,
but would simply be a gentle reminder given in the spirit of cooperation and good fellowship.
